oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Communication from Mrs. E. M. Hayes, wife of the late Oliver B. Hayes, listing thirteen line items including two mares, eighty-four head of sheep, five milk cows, and fifty-five hogs, total value of $3,142.00 dollars, that she claims were pressed into service by the Federal army during the Civil War. Includes response from Quartermaster suspending the claim to await "more positive proof of actual use by the US Army."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States -- Army -- Quartermaster's Dept.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The U. S. Army relied heavily on impressed goods while on campaign. While the Quartermaster furnished rations and other goods for the army, many items, such as horses, mules, wood, and animal feeds, were often taken from local populations. The U. S. government promised to reimburse individuals for impressed items through January 1, 1880, after which no further claims would be accepted.
